unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking of flying Indian Airways, huh? Let me tell you, as someone who's practically lived on their flights between Mumbai and Delhi for work, I've got some opinions. Firstly, booking tickets - their website can be a bit of a pain sometimes. Like, last month (08/2024), I spent a good 20 mins trying to book a seat. The UI needs a serious upgrade, guys!
normalised: Okay, so you're thinking of flying Indian Airways, huh? Let me tell you, as someone who's practically lived on their flights between Mumbai and Delhi for work, I've got some opinions. Firstly, booking tickets - their website can be a bit of a pain sometimes. Like, last month, August two thousand twenty four, I spent a good twenty minutes trying to book a seat. The U-I needs a serious upgrade, guys!

unnormalised: But, and this is a big but, once you get past the website woes, the in-flight experience is usually pretty decent. I've flown on the AI301 at 6:00 AM a bunch of times and surprisingly, it's usually on time. Plus, the food! Okay, maybe not Michelin star-worthy, but for airplane grub, it's not bad at all. They always seem to have good old masala chai available and that's a big win in my book. Give me that over some bland coffee any day.

unnormalised: The legroom? Well, let's just say if you're over 6 ft (like my colleague Rakesh), you might feel a little cramped. Try to snag an exit row seat if you can, or better yet, see if you can score an upgrade. Paying an extra Rs. 2000 for more space can make all the difference on a long flight. Trust me on this one!

Trust me on this one!

unnormalised: Now, the delays. Ah, the inevitable Indian airline delays. They happen. I remember one time in January (15/01/2023, to be exact), my flight from Guwahati was delayed by a whopping 4 hours. I was stuck at the airport, surviving on overpriced samosas and lukewarm coffee. So, yeah, pack a book or download some movies onto your phone just in case. You'll thank me later.

unnormalised: One thing I really appreciate is their baggage allowance. You get a decent 25 kg (kilograms) check-in baggage and 7 kg of cabin baggage. That's more than enough for most trips, unlike some budget airlines that nickel and dime you for every extra gram.

unnormalised: Also, the staff. They're generally friendly and helpful. I had this one really sweet air hostess, Priya, on a flight back from Kerala. She went out of her way to get me an extra blanket because the AC was blasting. Small gestures like that make a difference, you know?

unnormalised: So, overall, is flying Indian Airways worth it? It depends. If you're on a tight budget and flexible with your time, then yeah, go for it. But if you absolutely *need* to be somewhere on time, maybe consider another airline. Just remember to pack your patience, a good book, and maybe an extra samosa or two, and you'll be fine!
